announced manitoba will enter the 2nd phase of the 4-3-2 one great summer reopening path ahead of schedule after reaching the 75% threshold in 1st-dose vaccinations and 50% threshold for 2nd-dose vaccinations

increased limit on private indoor gatherings to a maximum of 5 people plus the household members and  indoor gatherings in public spaces to 25 people; increased private outdoor gatherings to a maximum of 25 people and public outdoor gatherings to 150 people; increased outdoor weddings and funerals to 150 people in addition to photographers and officiants; increased indoor weddings or funerals to 25 people in addition to photographers and officiants

increased retail businesses, restaurants, licensed premises and food court capacities to 50% or 500 people for retail businesses, whichever is lower; opening hours are extended to midnight and there are no longer restrictions on purchasing food with alcohol; outdoor maximum table size remains at 8 people, and patrons may only sit together indoors if they are from the same household or if all patrons 12 years of age or older are fully immunized (unvaccinated children under 12 may dine with fully vaccinated members of their household); faith-based and cultural gatherings may expand to 50% capacity or 150 people indoors, whichever is fewer (masks and physical distancing between households required); outdoor faith-based gatherings permitted up to 150 people; removed appointments requirement for personal services (haircuts and styling, nail salons, estheticians and massage)

increased dance, theatre and music schools to 50% capacity, or a maximum of 25 people per group; permitted movie theatres, casinos, museums and galleries to reopen for fully immunized people only; unvaccinated children under 12 may attend/visit these facilities if accompanied by fully vaccinated members of their household; permitted outdoor recreation including games and practices at a group size of 50 people; spectators are permitted and do not count toward this capacity limit; tournaments are not permitted; large-scale, outdoor professional sports or performing arts events may operate at 100% capacity with approval from public health; gyms and fitness centre capacities expand to 50% capacity with masks and physical distancing
increased day camp capacity to 25%; however, joint activities between groups and overnight camps are prohibited
indoor public gatherings and visitors to private property, except in certain circumstances, not permitted
issued order for several regulated health professionals to conduct nasopharyngeal swabs at covid-19 testing sites

who: college of registered nurses of manitoba
what: expedited temporary registration process to enable enhanced service provision by registered nurses during covid-19 pandemic

who: manitoba association of registered respiratory therapists
what: issued ministerial order to grant a temporary licence to former respiratory therapy practising members
announced 3,135 people hired to assist with manitoba's vaccination efforts including immunizers, clinic managers, clinical leads, system navigators and observers
announced recruitment of physicians at immunization super sites to answer questions or concerns of individuals prior to receiving vaccine

who: government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: travellers returning to n.b. from outside canada are required to self-monitor for symptoms for 14 days.

who: government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: restricted long-term care visitors with any symptoms and/or recent international travel.

suspended visitors in acute care facilities except for palliative care, intensive care, critical care and neonatal intensive care, obstetrics and pediatrics, discharge, pediatric patients or emergency department support, for which 1 visitor is permitted.
amended restrictions to hospital visitation — total ban except for palliative care, obstetric and pediatric (including child psychiatry) units (1 permitted)
announcing opening of new assessment sites to offload emergency room

who: government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: child care centres to close with exception of those for essential health care workers

who: government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: recommended private companies allow employees to work from home where possible and focus on critical activities

who: horizon health network and vitalité health network
what: elective procedures cancelled and postponed. no mandate found on provincial site.

who: government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: all non-essential government services closed

who: government of new brunswick, office of the chief medical officer of health
what: announced that regulated health professions only to provide emergency or urgent care. non-regulated health professions must close. this excludes home support workers.

who: office of the premier, government of new brunswick
what: closure of post-secondary education institutions. institutions that have students in residence are permitted to allow them to remain in residence until they can safely return home. online course delivery may continue.

who: government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: businesses asked to take all reasonable steps to avoid gatherings of more than 10 people. not formally prohibited.

who: office of the premier, government of new brunswick
what: restricted food and beverage services to takeout and delivery only. closed barbers, hair stylists and esthetics service providers.

who: office of the premier, government of new brunswick
what: ordered closures of some private businesses and public spaces, including swimming pools, spas, saunas, waterparks, gymnasiums, yoga studios, dance studios, rinks and arenas, tennis courts, soccer and baseball fields, climbing walls, escape rooms, ski hills, golf courses, arcades, amusement centres, pool halls, bowling alleys, casinos, cinemas, libraries, museums, zoos, aquariums, sugar bush operations, and theatres or other live performance venues

who: department of tourism, heritage and culture
what: closed provincial parks until further notice, following federal government decision for national parks

who: government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: launched a self-assessment online tool
travellers returning to n.b. from outside n.b. are required to self-isolate for 14 days.
testing criteria expanded to include health care workers who have not travelled but have developed cough, fever or shortness of breath

who: office of the premier, government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: further changes to testing criteria to focus on symptomatic health care workers and prison staff, hospitalized patients with respiratory symptoms and no alternative diagnosis, and residents of long-term care facilities and other vulnerable communities
modified registration requirements for pharmacist and pharmacy technicians not entitled to practise direct client care through conditional: emergency registration on an expedited basis and at no cost

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: announced that k–12 schools will not reopen for the remainder of the school year unless the covid-19 situation drastically improves
released projections for cases and critical care capacity

who: office of the premier, government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: updated testing criteria to now include people exhibiting at least 2 of the following 5 symptoms: fever above 38°c; a new cough or worsening chronic cough; sore throat; runny nose; and headache

who: office of the premier, government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: process created for public and private businesses to donate personal protective equipment

who: office of the premier, government of new brunswick, chief medical officer of health
what: gardening and agricultural retailers to reopen — deemed essential to food supply
advised that all non-essential/non-emergency dental treatment and services should be suspended.
launched online portal for the public to easily access their covid-19 lab test results

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: released 4-stage recovery plan to loosen public health restrictions, with some measures effective immediately

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: recommendation to wear non-medical masks when physical distancing may not be possible

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: extended prohibition on large gatherings such as festivals and concerts

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted households to spend time with 1 other household, forming a 2-household bubble. selection is not interchangeable. carpooling permitted as long as the passenger is in the back seat and can maintain distancing.

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: students requiring access to campus to fulfill their course requirements will be able to do so.

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: golf courses and driving ranges, recreational fishing and hunting, and outdoor spaces to reopen as long as physical distancing measures in place. playgrounds continue to be closed. outdoor religious services permitted as long as attendees stay in vehicles 2 metres apart.

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: expanded testing criteria to include those with a new onset of fatigue; a new onset of muscle pain; diarrhea; loss of sense of taste or loss of sense of smell; and in children, purple markings on the fingers or toes

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: restricted new temporary foreign workers from entering new brunswick

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: post-secondary students returning to other provinces are permitted to enter and retrieve belongings for 24 hours. anyone staying more than 24 hours is expected to self-isolate for 14 days.

implemented permanent telehealth standard permitting practice via telehealth, including consultations and follow-ups. registrants must inform the new brunswick chiropractors association prior to beginning telehealth services.
published list of "strong recommendations" (decontamination of offices, etc.). recommendations are best practices, and all chiropractors are strongly urged to adopt these new public health measures.
updated the 2020-04-24 return to practice recommendations

announced that zoom for healthcare video conferencing platform available free of charge for 1 year to dietitians to support delivery of remote dietetic services. zoom will be available for 1 year from date of activation.

who: government of new brunswick, office of the chief medical officer of health
what: pharmacists may use their judgment and the options available to them to reduce non-essential physician visits, including those for prescription renewals. pharmacists should not hesitate to provide emergency fills, particularly in the case of expired prescriptions that would otherwise require a prescriber visit.

who: government of new brunswick, office of the chief medical officer of health
what: prohibited staff working in long-term care/residential facilities from working in different facilities; facilities initiated active screening of employees at entry of the facility; essential visitors/staff in nursing homes to be provided 2 surgical masks per shift
all unnecessary travel into n.b. is prohibited, and peace officers are authorized to turn such travellers away.
all social gatherings prohibited
increased the limit on indoor and outdoor gatherings to 10 people or fewer
announced resumption of elective surgeries
permitted regulated health professionals to offer non-emergency services, in compliance with additional guidance from their respective regulatory bodies
opened post-secondary institutions, recommending virtual options where possible
opened non-regulated child care centres, provided that they follow guidelines and have an operational plan; regulated early learning and child care centres scheduled to open on may 19
opened offices, malls and retail businesses
permitted libraries, museums, galleries, campgrounds and outdoor recreational businesses to open, provided that operational guidelines are met

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: announced new rules for end of life visits in hospitals, long-term care homes and hospices. patients/residents may designate 2 visitors who may visit only 1 at a time.

opened trails for sugarloaf provincial park. more provincial parks to open throughout may and june. services limited to trails and beaches, public washrooms, limited restaurant services (where applicable) and seasonal and daily camping.

who: department of health, department of agriculture, aquaculture and fisheries
what: farmers' markets may open as long as they develop an operational plan; each individual vendor must develop an operational plan as well

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: schools open for teachers only in june
previously established 2-household bubbles may be expanded to include more close friends and family; indoor gathering should be limited to 10 people
permitted non-regulated health professionals to resume in-person services
allowed personal services businesses (e.g., barbers, hair stylists, spas, estheticians) to resume in-person services
increased the limit on outdoor gatherings to 50 people or fewer; funeral and wedding services with distancing permitted for 50 people or fewer

opened park playgrounds, swimming pools, saunas and waterparks, gyms, yoga and dance studios, rinks and indoor recreational facilities, and pool halls and bowling alleys; low-contact sports leagues permitted to resume provided that they maintain an operational plan

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health
what: outdoor religious services permitted as long as attendees stay in vehicles 2 metres apart

who: premier, chief medical officer of health

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted long-term care residents up to 2 visitors for outdoor visits with physical distancing requirements; zone 5 excluded

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted long-term care residents 1 visitor at a time for indoor visits, with physical distancing requirements; if the visitor requires support, then 2 visitors permitted; zone 5 excluded

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted day and overnight camps to open with a requirement for an operational plan, zone 5 excluded

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted canadian residents owning property in n.b. or having immediate family in n.b. to enter the province provided that they self-isolate for 14 days
mandated the wearing of masks in buildings open to the public and in other public spaces where distancing cannot be maintained

expanded testing criteria to include anyone with fever above 38°c or signs of fever (such as chills), a new cough or worsening chronic cough, sore throat, runny nose, headache, a new onset of fatigue, a new onset of muscle pain, diarrhea, loss of sense of taste or loss of sense of smell and, in children, purple markings on the fingers or toes
lifted requirement for n.b. residents to self-isolate after returning from work in another province or territory, but still expected to self-monitor
permitted all remaining businesses to open, zone 5 included
permitted all remaining businesses to open, zone 5 included

who: office of the premier, chief medical officer of health

what: zone 5 entered phase 3 (yellow) of the recovery plan.
formed an atlantic travel bubble with p.e.i., n.l. and n.s., allowing residents of atlantic canada to enter n.b. for non-essential travel

formed an atlantic travel bubble with p.e.i., n.l. and n.s., allowing residents of atlantic canada to enter n.b. without self-isolating for 14 days, provided that they have not travelled outside of the atlantic provinces

released the travel registration program, a pre-travel registration service for health screening and preparation of travel documentation; all persons entering n.b. must register and anyone arriving at the border without registering will be required to do so at the border

who: department of health, department of public safety
what: lifted requirement to self-isolate for day trip travellers from the n.b.-que. border communities of avignon municipal regional county, listuguj first nation and the témiscouata municipal regional county, provided that they have not travelled outside of these communities
extended the provincial state of emergency

mandated that venues with seating for the purposes of eating, drinking, socialization, celebration, ceremony or entertainment must maintain a record of names and contact information of seated patrons; hosts or organizers of gatherings larger than 50 required to do the same

zone 5 re-entered the yellow level and permitted long-term care residents up to 2 visitors for outdoor visits and 1 visitor for indoor visits (visitors requiring support are permitted to have a second person) with distancing

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: released plan and safety guidance, entitled "return to school: september 2020," for reopening elementary, middle and high schools in the fall; k-8 students will have full time in-person learning, and grades 9 to 12 will have a blended approach

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted gradual reopening of regulated child care centres and early learning, starting with 50% of locations opened immediately and 80% expected to open by june 1.

permitted day camps to open, provided that operational guidelines are met

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: zone 5 re-entered the yellow level, permitting non-regulated health professionals to reopen

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: zone 5 re-entered the yellow level, permitting the expansion of household bubbles to include more close friends and family; increased the limit on uncontrolled outdoor gatherings to 50 people or fewer; lifted limits on controlled venues, and occupancy is based on the ability to maintain distancing

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: revised the gatherings limits, distinguishing between controlled and uncontrolled venues: lifted the gatherings limit on controlled venues (such as churches, water parks, indoor recreational facilities), instead basing occupancy only on the ability to maintain distancing; kept limit on gatherings in uncontrolled outdoor venues at 50
virtual care billing code released for physicians
released operational plan to guide dentists through safe reopening procedures for non-essential dental services

who: new brunswick college of dental hygienists

revised the public health recovery alert levels (red, orange, yellow and green); public health measures were revised and new triggers included for the movement between alert levels
permitted long-term care residents to take day or overnight off-site visits and permitted facilities to reintroduce designated support people (often family)

announced that testing in the fall will be expanded to include individuals experiencing mild symptoms or only 1 symptom, asymptomatic staff and volunteers at long-term care facilities, first nations community health centres, provincial correctional facilities and homeless shelters

restricted travel from the que. border community of témiscouata municipal regional county; residents no longer permitted to make day trips, and previously approved registrations for day trips no longer valid; essential travel for reasons such as medical appointments, approved work and shared child custody continue to be exempt
travellers from the que. border community of témiscouata municipal regional county required to self-isolate for 14 days when entering n.b., unless exempt

restricted travel from the que. border community of avignon municipal regional county; residents no longer permitted to make day trips, and previously approved registrations for day trips no longer valid; essential travel for reasons such as medical appointments, approved work and shared child custody continue to be exempt
travellers from the que. border community of avignon municipal regional county required to self-isolate for 14 days when entering n.b., unless exempt

who: department of health, department of education and early childhood development
what: released return to school: guide for parents and the public, a general guidance document outlining what students and parents need to know before returning to school: all students are to bring a mask but are not required to wear them inside classrooms; masks required for grades 6 to 12 on school buses and in common areas; for teachers, masks are optional in k-8 and required for grades 9 to 12; k-5 will be taught in cohorts (reduced sizes for k-5) with no distancing required; grades 9 to 12 will be required to follow distancing of 1 metre in the classroom and 2 metres in common areas

who: department of health, department of education and early childhood development
what: described an outbreak in a school as a confirmed case of covid-19; previously, defined an outbreak as a single confirmed case or 2 suspected cases of covid-19 in early childhood learning facilities (see secondary source from may 2020)

who: department of health, department of education and early childhood development

who: department of health, department of education and early childhood development
what: updated return to school plans to reflect changes to group sizes for in-person and guidance on music education: k-2 will have group sizes around 15 and grades 3 to 6 will have group sizes around 22; singing and wind instruments permitted with measures in place

who: department of education and early childhood development

what: all regions are in phase 1 (red), as part of the initial pandemic response

restricted travel from the que. border communities of listuguj first nation and pointe-à-la-croix; residents no longer permitted to make day trips, and previously approved registrations for day trips no longer valid; essential travel for reasons such as medical appointments, approved work, k-12 school and shared child custody continue to be exempt

who: office of the premier, department of health

released updated covid-19 vaccination plan with 4 phases

announced that the 1st phase of the covid-19 vaccination plan includes first nations adults over 16. the 2nd phase in apr. will target residents and staff in communal settings; health care workers providing direct care; first responders; home support workers for seniors; individuals age 70 and older; individuals with select complex medical conditions; volunteers and designated support people in long-term care; individuals age 40 or older with 3 or more chronic conditions; and truckers, rotational workers and regular cross-border work commuters. the 3rd phase in jun. will target health care workers providing indirect care; people with 2 or more select chronic conditions; school staff; and students between the ages of 16 and 24. the 4th phase expected in jul. will be widely available for all new brunswickers.

who: department of health and community services
what: suspended hospital visits except for end of life care and birth. parents can visit inpatient children. recommended previously on 03-12-2020 for those with symptoms to not visit.

who: department of health and community services
what: restricted long-term care visits - 1 designated visitor allowed per resident.

who: department of health and community services
what: postponed elective procedures.

who: minister of education and early childhood development
what: regulated child care centres to close
closure of post-secondary education institutions; suspended classes — first closure reported in newfoundland

who: newfoundland and labrador english school district
what: closure of elementary, middle and high schools; closed indefinitely
closure of post-secondary education institutions; suspended classes

who: department of health and community services
what: published webpage for information on self-isolation (cases, contacts and symptoms)

who: minister of education and early childhood development
what: regulated child care homes to close
closures to non-essential businesses
closed bars and limited restaurants to takeout only

who: government of newfoundland and labrador, premier
what: travellers returning to n.l. from outside n.l. are required to self-isolate for 14 days.
prohibited gatherings of more than 50 people

who: college of physicians and surgeons of newfoundland and labrador
what: announced that if requested by a regional health authority, the college may issue an emergency licence to a physician to provide medical services in relation to the current public health state of emergency
prohibited gatherings of more than 10 people

who: department of health and community services
what: amended restrictions to visitation - long-term care facilities closed to all visitors.
ordered closures of private health clinics (e.g., dentists, audiologists, physiotherapists, chiropractors).
non-essential travel is no longer permitted on provincial ferries.

who: department of tourism, culture, industry and innovation
what: postponed provincial park campsite reservations; opening dates are to be determined as the situation develops.
released safety guidelines for pharmacy staff around the use of personal protective equipment; measures to reduce the risk of exposure within the pharmacy environment

who: newfoundland and labrador occupational therapists board
what: waived or modified registration requirements for former or out-of-province occupational therapists, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic on an expedited basis and at no cost

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: cancelled elementary, middle and high schools’ public exams and final exams

who: department of fisheries and land resources
what: closed trails and visitor centres for numerous trails and parks. guided tours cancelled for the season.
released projections for cases and critical care capacity

expanded testing criteria to include anyone with 2 or more symptoms such as a fever — or signs of a fever, which include chills, sweats, muscle aches or light-headedness — a cough, headache, sore throat or a runny nose can be tested.
advised optometrists to provide urgent and emergency care only if needed.

who: government of newfoundland and labrador, chief medical officer of health
what: issued order banning employees from working in more than 1 facility/site, due to concerns about transmitting the virus between facilities/sites

who: chief medical officer of health, department of health and community services
what: released 5-stage "a foundation for living with covid-19" plan for reopening the province

who: chief medical officer of health, department of health and community services
what: permitted households to spend time with 1 other household, forming a 2-household bubble
prohibited gatherings of more than 5 people
province requiring all individuals arriving from outside the province to submit a 14-day self-isolation plan to public health
prohibited staff at personal care homes and long-term care facilities from working at any other place of employment, like a grocery store

who: department of health and community services
what: announced new travel restrictions. only residents of the province, asymptomatic workers and individuals subject to the updated exemption order effective 2020-04-22, and individuals who have been permitted entry to the province by the chief medical officer of health may enter the province

who: government of newfoundland and labrador, chief medical officer of health
what: asymptomatic health care workers essential to the provision of critical health care in the province are exempted from the requirement to self-isolate for 14 days, only while these workers are travelling to and from their home and place of work in the province.

who: department of transportation and works, chief medical officer of health
what: lifted prior restrictions on provincial ferries to essential travel only; ferries to operate at half capacity with distancing measures in place

who: department of health and community services
what: gatherings of 10 permitted for funerals, burials and weddings only; individuals instructed to remain in their 2-household bubble.

who: department of health and community services
what: opened municipal parks except for playground equipment and encouraged outdoor activity. recreational angling and hunting is permitted. golf courses and driving ranges permitted to open, with some restrictions.

who: department of health and community services
what: permitted regulated child care centres to open for operation at 50% capacity or a maximum of 30 persons per facility

who: department of health and community services
what: opened animal daycare centres and garden centres. landscaping services permitted to resume. professional services such as law firms permitted to offer in-person services.

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: announced that schools will remain closed for the rest of the school year

who: department of education and early childhood development

who: department of health and community services

who: department of health and community services
what: allowed patients to schedule a virtual appointment with a nurse practitioner for urgent, non-emergency care

who: department of health and community services
what: all regions entered alert level 4 of "a foundation for living with covid-19."

who: department of health and community services

who: department of health and community services
what: permitted outdoor pools to open; permitted provincial, municipal and private campgrounds to open for overnight access to self-contained units; allowed resumption of medium-risk outdoor activities, including sports

who: department of health and community services

who: department of health and community services
what: permitted places of worship and bars and lounges to open

who: department of health and community services

who: department of health and community services

who: department of health and community services
what: amended special measures order to stipulate that bars may only operate at 50% capacity

expanded testing criteria to include anyone with 2 of fever (or signs of fever, including chills, sweats, muscle aches and lightheadedness), cough, headache, sore throat, painful swallowing, runny nose, unexplained loss of appetite/diarrhea, loss of sense of smell or taste or small red or purple spots on the hands and/or feet

who: department of health and community services

what: communities in the st. george’s, stephenville, port au port area on the west side of the trans-canada highway in alert level 4, limited funerals and religious ceremonies limited to 10 people with distancing; all other gatherings limited to those individuals within same household

what: communities in the lewisporte to summerford area under alert level 3, permitted gatherings up to a maximum of 20 people for funerals, burials, weddings and religious and cultural ceremonies, with distancing; all other informal gatherings limited to 10 consistent contacts from outside each household

who: department of health and community services
what: communities along the trans-canada highway route 1 from gambo to badger under alert level 2, public visitations are permitted, with 1 household bubble visiting at a time

who: department of health and community services

what: towns and communities along highway route 403 in alert level 4; limited funerals and religious ceremonies to 10 people with distancing; all other gatherings limited to those individuals within same household

announced that residents of atlantic canada can enter newfoundland and labrador without the requirement for testing and self-isolation

who: department of health and community services
what: updated travel form, which all travellers are required to fill out prior to arriving in newfoundland and labrador; this travel form must be submitted 72 hours prior to arrival and must be accompanied by proof of covid-19 vaccination and/or a negative test result; people who are currently in self-isolation can complete and upload the new form to be able to leave isolation as of july 1; if travelling from within the atlantic provinces, a form will need to be completed but vaccination status is not required

who: department of health and community services
what: announced the province will enter step 1 of together. again., the province's reopening plan after reaching 75% threshold in 1st dose vaccinations

who: department of health and community services
what: announced that the province is now in step 1 of together. again., the province's reopening plan (see nl303 for detailed restrictions)

who: department of health and community services
what: announced that the province is now in step 1 of together. again., the province's reopening plan (see nl304 for detailed restrictions)

what: announced that the province is now in step 1 of together. again., the province's reopening plan (see nl305 for detailed restrictions)

who: department of health and community services
what: announced that the province is now in step 1 of together. again., the province's reopening plan (see nl306 for detailed restrictions)

who: department of health and community services
what: announced that the province is now in step 1 of together. again., the province's reopening plan (see nl307 for detailed restrictions)
announced the commencement of the 1st phase to accelerate 2nd-dose administration: those who are due for their 2nd dose will be able to move their appointment up to within 8 weeks of their 1st dose

updated visitor restrictions for patients in hospital and long-term care residents: there will no longer be a requirement for patients/residents to have a list of 6 designated visitors, and all facilities will permit 2 visitors per day unless advised by the care team

updated visitor restrictions at eastern health facilities to allow visitors from outside of atlantic canada, provided the individual is not self-isolating, does not have covid-19 symptoms and meets all other screening criteria for visitation
announced that routine surveillance covid-19 testing for hospital admissions will no longer be required

announced that those who received their 1st dose between mar. 26 and apr. 15 and have their 2nd appointment scheduled between july 16 and aug. 5 are eligible to change their 2nd dose appointment to an earlier date; those who have received a 1st dose of astrazeneca or covishield between mar. 2 and apr. 15 and would like to receive an mrna vaccine for their 2nd dose are eligible to book an appointment for a pfizer or moderna clinic

announced that earlier 2nd doses of covid-19 vaccination will be available for individuals who had their 2nd-dose vaccination appointments booked on or after aug. 6 (interval between 1st and 2nd doses must be a minimum of 8 weeks)
announced that those who have received astrazeneca for their 1st dose can choose to receive either an mrna vaccine or astrazeneca as their 2nd dose
announced that following public health recommendations, the minimum interval between doses of covid-19 vaccine has been reduced to 28 days
launched a dedicated government web page for covid-19 (earliest publication date tracked using wayback machine)

who: nova scotia college of respiratory therapists
what: published information on emergency registration requirements for retired/inactive/out-of-province/student respiratory therapists, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic

who: government of nova scotia, department of health and wellness
what: travellers returning to n.s. from outside canada are asked to self-isolate for 14 days.
opening of 8 assessment centres across the province
closed provincial museums and art galleries
suspended all visitation at long-term care facilities.

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: regulated child care centres to close, to be reassessed after 2 weeks

who: nova scotia college of medical laboratory technologists
what: waived or modified registration requirements for former medical laboratory technologists, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic on an expedited basis and at no cost
prohibited gatherings of more than 50 people

who: nova scotia health authority and iwk health centre
what: elective procedures postponed — not a provincial mandate but provided links to nsha and iwk sites.

who: nova scotia health authority and iwk health centre
what: nsha and iwk restricted hospital visits.
closed bars and limited restaurants to takeout and delivery only
closed private businesses including gyms, spas and salons
announced that dentists can no longer practise except for emergency procedures.
launched a self-assessment online tool (date found using internet archive)
closed provincial parks until further notice
prohibited gatherings of more than 5 people
border restrictions tightened to limit non-essential travel at land, air and sea. these do not apply to healthy essential workers and people travelling for essential health services.

who: government of nova scotia, department of health and wellness
what: announced that regulated health professions may only to provide emergency or urgent care. this excludes doctors, pharmacists, nurse practitioners, nurses and paramedics. non-regulated health professions must close. this excludes podiatrists and ocularists.

expanded testing criteria to include anyone referred by 811 to an assessment centre, all close contacts of people who test positive, and people in hospital who meet the criteria for testing. new phone line created for health care workers.

who: college of physicians and surgeons of nova scotia
what: announced that recently retired nova scotia physicians can apply for a restricted licence to help in the pandemic response at no cost. this restricted licence is time-limited and specific to addressing the response to covid-19 as directed by nsha and iwk.

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: closure of elementary, middle and high schools extended

continued care prescription agreements with the college of physicians and surgeons and the nova scotia college of nursing are no longer in effect. this means that pharmacists must now prescribe a renewal in order to extend the supply of a patient’s existing prescription.
expanded testing options to include additions of temporary primary assessment centres, a mobile assessment centre, emergency health services assessment units and expanded lab capacity
removal of travel as a requirement for testing

revisions to symptom screening — anyone with 2 or more of the following symptoms should visit https://811.novascotia.ca/ to determine if they should call 811 for further assessment: fever, new or worsening cough, sore throat, runny nose, headache

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: closed private campgrounds
temporarily suspended the 180 days prescription renewal limit

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: released projections for cases
published guideline on amendments to drug administration standards, expanding the authority to administer drugs not previously administered by pharmacists

who: provincial dental board of nova scotia
what: suspended of all non-essential/non-emergency treatment and services

who: college of physicians and surgeons of nova scotia
what: recommend using virtual care and announce new billing codes for virtual care

who: college of physicians and surgeons of nova scotia
what: allowed physicians to work outside their normal scope of practice; they will not face disciplinary measures for doing so

who: midwifery regulatory council of nova scotia
what: all midwives (employees of the iwk or the nova scotia health authority) are prohibited from entering clients’ homes. they are directed to care for patients in hospital/clinic settings only.

who: college of physicians and surgeons of nova scotia
what: announced granting of defined licence to new graduated, canadian-trained, post-graduate trainees, which requires sponsorship and supervision. the review of qualifications fee of $350 will be refunded to these trainees applying for licensure.
published guidelines on pharmacy infection control measures, including staff safety
travellers returning to n.s. from outside n.s. are required to self-isolate for 14 days.
restricted visitors who travelled internationally in the past 14 days.

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: extended closure of public schools

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: extended closure of licensed child care centres and will reassess at a future date
released preliminary plans to lift some restrictions and announced that a phased plan to further lift restrictions is under development — did not later release nor follow a final phased plan

initial set of restrictions lifted. provincial/municipal parks, trails and other outdoor spaces reopen. garden centres, nurseries and similar businesses may reopen. sport fishing and boating is permitted. sailing and yacht clubs may reopen for boat preparations only. golf driving ranges may reopen but golf courses to remain closed. drive-in religious services permitted as long as people remain in vehicle and maintain physical distancing.

who: nova scotia college of audiologists and speech-language pathologists
what: published guidance for practising telemedicine during the covid-19 pandemic

who: premier and chief medical officer of health
what: opened outdoor facilities for archery, equestrianism, golf, paddling, sailing/boating and tennis. organized events, coaching or training are not permitted. opened public beaches.
households permitted to form a 2-household bubble with a household of immediate family

expanded testing criteria to include any of fever (i.e., chills, sweats), cough or worsening of a previous cough, sore throat, headache, shortness of breath, muscle aches, sneezing, nasal congestion/runny nose, hoarse voice, diarrhea, unusual fatigue, loss of sense of smell or taste, red and purple or blueish lesions on the feet, toes or fingers without clear cause

who: premier and chief medical officer of health
what: permitted restaurants for dine-in, bars, wineries, distilleries and taprooms and fitness/sporting facilities to open

who: premier and chief medical officer of health
what: permitted personal services (i.e., hair salons, barbershops, spas, nail salons and body art establishments) and veterinary clinics to open

who: premier and chief medical officer of health
what: regulated and unregulated health professionals permitted to open, provided that they follow protocols outlined by their college or association

who: nova scotia health authority and iwk health centre
what: resumed midwifery services for home births
recommended wearing a non-medical mask where distancing may be difficult

who: iwk health centre, nova scotia health authority
what: allowing up to 2 support persons for childbirth, end of life care and pediatric patients
announced resumption of some procedures and services including ambulatory (outpatient) clinics, diagnostic imaging, laboratory and surgery services

who: government of nova scotia, office of the premier
what: announced cash bonus (up to $2,000) for those in the health care sector supporting covid-19 response
drive-in religious services permitted as long as people remain in vehicle and maintain physical distancing
published a definition of a suspect covid-19 outbreak in long-term care as a single case in a resident or staff member and symptoms as per the testing criteria

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: increased the limit on indoor and outdoor gatherings to 10 people or fewer, provided physical distancing measures are in place; permitted outdoor weddings and funerals of up to 15 people

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted private campgrounds to open to all campers at 50% capacity

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted provincial campgrounds to open to nova scotians at reduced capacity, to maintain 20 feet of distance between campsites

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: permitted licensed child care centres to open at 50% capacity, with a possibility to operate at full capacity if able to follow guidelines; opened family daycare homes at full operating capacity

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted long-term care residents up to 2 visitors for scheduled outdoor visits in long-term care facilities and homes for persons with disabilities
permitted day camps to open provided that they have a plan on how to adhere to guidelines; group sizes limited to 10

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted gatherings of up to 10 without the need to distance (replacing household bubbles), but strongly encouraged to maintain a consistent group; increased the limit on large gatherings to 50 people or fewer, provided physical distancing measures are in place

who: premier, chief medical officer of health
what: permitted playgrounds to open

who: college of physicians and surgeons of nova scotia
what: released guidelines for physicians for the resumption of services in medical practices, including virtual care and personal protective equipment

who: nova scotia college of audiologists and speech-language pathologists
what: published guidelines for adapting the physical environment, and outlined routine practices for a safe workplace

who: provincial dental board of nova scotia
what: published guidance for safe resumption of comprehensive dental care including emergency, urgent and elective (non-urgent) services
published guidance on self-isolation for recent travellers (earliest publication date estimated using wayback machine)
formed an atlantic travel bubble with p.e.i., n.b. and n.l., allowing residents of atlantic canada to enter n.s. for non-essential travel
formed an atlantic travel bubble with p.e.i., n.b. and n.l., allowing residents of atlantic canada to enter n.s. without self-isolating for 14 days

who: department of communities, culture and heritage
what: initiated a phased approach to reopening museums, starting with 13 locations

permitted businesses and organizations to hold outdoor gatherings of 250 and indoor gatherings of 200 (or a capacity limit of 50%), with distancing; gatherings not organized by a recognized business or organization remain subject to the limit of 50 persons
permitted public pools to reopen with restrictions and private campgrounds to operate at 100% capacity
permitted restaurants and licensed liquor establishments to operate at 100% capacity with distancing between tables and patrons required to leave by 1 a.m.
opened provincial campgrounds to residents of other atlantic provinces and announced the opening of additional provincial campsites on july 6

who: department of health and wellness, department of environment
what: announced a mandatory tracking and self-declaration form for travellers from outside the atlantic travel bubble
reopened visitor centres at halifax waterfront, amherst, peggy’s cove, port hastings and yarmouth

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: mandated the wearing of a non-medical mask on public transportation for drivers and passengers; exemption for children under 2 and persons with a valid medical reason

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted long-term care home residents to designate 3 visitors who may visit 1 at a time during scheduled indoor visits and up to 5 visitors for scheduled outdoor visits

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: mandated the wearing of a non-medical mask in most indoor public spaces; exemption for children under 2, children 2 to 4 who refuse to wear a mask and persons with a valid medical reason

who: premier, department of education and early childhood development
what: released "nova scotia's back to school plan," a plan and safety guidance for elementary, middle and high schools to open in the fall with safety measures in place: students in k-8 will have in-school learning with reduced class sizes and cohorting, and students in 9-12 will have a blended approach primarily using remote learning; within class cohorts, distancing is recommended but not necessary at all times; distancing is required at all times between cohorts

who: provincial dental board of nova scotia
what: released guidelines for dental offices to provide comprehensive (emergent, urgent and non-urgent) dental treatment in their offices
released guidelines for dietitians for returning to in-person nutrition care services
released return to work safety guidelines for optometrists

who: college of occupational therapists of nova scotia
what: released directives for private sector occupational therapists for resuming non-urgent/elective practice

who: nova scotia board of examiners in psychology
what: released guidelines for safe return to in-person practice for psychologists

who: department of health and wellness, department of labour and advanced education
what: announced that post-secondary students arriving from outside the atlantic bubble are required to be tested 3 times during their 14-day self-isolation period; students are required to self-isolate for a full 14 days even if test results are negative
permitted long-term care residents to leave for medical appointments accompanied by family members; lifted the limit on the number of people a resident may designate as visitors
revised testing criteria to any fever or cough (new or worsening), or 2 of (new or worsening) sore throat, runny nose, headache or shortness of breath

permitted long-term care residents to designate 2 caregivers, who may visit 1 at a time; caregivers must be associated with specific tasks and have an established caregiving relationship with the resident

eased self-isolation requirements for rotational workers (someone who rotates in a scheduled manner between living in n.s. and working out of province); permitted rotational workers to take part in list of low-risk and non-contact activities alone or with family without the need to self-isolate (international workers excepted); additionally, permitted rotational workers to attend urgent and routine medical appointments, on september 14

who: department of health and wellness, department of communities, culture and heritage
what: permitted gatherings of up to 50 without the need to distance for the performing arts, sports and other organized physical activities; unorganized or casual games such as pickup basketball are still subject to a limit of 10 people without distancing measures or 50 people with distancing measures
permitted long-term care residents to have pre-arranged off-site day visits, with some health measures in place; overnight trips not permitted nor any trips outside of the atlantic bubble
extended availability of physician payment codes for virtual visits to december 31

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: mandated the use of non-medical masks in schools for students in grades 4 to 12, except when they are seated at desks 2 metres apart and facing the same direction

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: updated nova scotia's back to school plan to reflect new group size limits of 15 for after-school program cohorts

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: released nova scotia's back to school plan, a guidance document including outbreak management and other operational information: key elements include a symptom screener (based on test criteria symptom list); keeping communities informed; the role of local public health offices in leading case and contact tracing activities, declaring outbreaks and directing closure of classrooms or schools where necessary; and protocols to trigger public health responses or infection control measures

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: defined an outbreak in a school as 1 confirmed case of covid-19 connected to the school

who: department of health and wellness, department of education and early childhood development
what: opened public schools for first day of classes

revised the symptom list in the daily covid-19 checklist linked in nova scotia's back to school plan to reflect the new symptoms in the test criteria: any fever or cough (new or worsening), or 2 of (new or worsening) sore throat, runny nose/nasal congestion, headache or shortness of breath
announced guidelines for safe reopening of private physiotherapy practice

announced streamlining of covid-19 online self-assessment tool: people who fill out the online self-assessment and meet the test criteria will be contacted by the nova scotia health authority or iwk health within 24 to 48 hours, instead of having to book an appointment through 811
announced that the national exposure notification app covid alert is now available in n.s.

who: department of labour and advanced education
what: permitted international students to enter n.s. for post-secondary education after subjected to self-isolation requirements; post-secondary institutions are responsible for oversight of students, quarantine accommodations and transportation from airports

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: announced gradual opening of school gyms for community physical activity and sports

implemented stricter self-isolation requirements for non-essential travel from outside the atlantic bubble: upon arrival of the person travelling for non-essential reasons, all members in the hosting home are required to self-isolate for 14 days; visitors are not permitted and no one in the home may leave the property

for halifax regional municipality and hants county (some areas excluded), limited social gatherings to a maximum of 5 (or the total number of members of a household) without the need to distance; limited organized outdoor gatherings to a maximum of 150 and indoor gatherings to a maximum of 50% capacity or 100, with distancing; limited unorganized gatherings to a maximum of 25
restricted off-site visits for residents in long-term care to a sight-seeing car ride provided by a designated caregiver
mandated that full-service restaurants and licensed establishments collect contact information from at least one person in each party and retain the information for 4 weeks
for halifax regional municipality and hants county (some areas excluded), expanded mandatory masking to include commons areas of multi-unit residential buildings
for halifax regional municipality and hants county (some areas excluded), limited restaurants and liquor serving establishments to takeout only; paused faith-based activities

for halifax regional municipality and hants county (some areas excluded) paused organized sport, recreational, athletic, arts and cultural activities; closed libraries, museums, gyms and recreational facilities, casinos and first nations gaming establishments; restricted retail stores to 25% capacity
suspended visitation in long-term care, adult residential centres and regional rehabilitation centres, except for volunteers and designated caregivers

expanded testing criteria to include asymptomatic persons who have many social contacts, have not travelled outside the atlantic provinces in the past 14 days, have not visited a potential exposure location and have not been in close contact with a confirmed case
recommended asymptomatic testing for rotational workers on day 6, 7 or 8 of self-isolation
amended recommendation for asymptomatic testing of rotational workers to include a test on day 1 or 2 of self-isolation, in addition to the previously recommended test on day 6, 7 or 8
recommended asymptomatic testing for post-secondary students on day 6, 7 or 8 of self-isolation
extended availability of physician payment codes for virtual visits to march 31
winter holiday break took place from december 21 to january 8, inclusive
required restaurants and licensed establishments to stop service at 10 p.m. and close by 11 p.m.; limited retail stores to 25% capacity
for halifax regional municipality and hants county (some areas excluded), increased the limit on social gatherings to 10 without the need to distance, realigning with the rest of the province
limited organized outdoor gatherings (faith gatherings, weddings and funerals) to a maximum of 150 and indoor gatherings to a maximum of 50% capacity or 100, with distancing

limited fitness facilities to 50% capacity with 3-metre distancing for intense activities; prohibited social events, festivals, special events, arts/cultural events and sports events; sports practices, training and arts and culture rehearsals remain permitted with up to 25 without distancing (games, tournaments and performances prohibited)
permitted long-term care residents to have 2 designated caregivers and for each facility to have a limited number of scheduled visits
expanded test criteria to include asymptomatic bar staff and patrons in halifax regional municipality and hants county

for halifax regional municipality and hants county, permitted restaurants and licensed establishments to resume dine-in services, subject to the requirements of ending service at 10 p.m. and closing by 11 p.m.
amended the atlantic travel bubble rules, requiring people entering n.s. from n.b. to complete the nova scotia safe check-in form prior to arrival
amended the atlantic travel bubble rules, requiring people entering n.s. from n.b. to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival, with some exceptions
announced mandatory asymptomatic testing of rotational workers: workers must be tested once on day 1 or 2 and a second time on day 6, 7 or 8, or may be subject to a $1000 fine

who: midwifery regulatory council of nova scotia
what: announced approval for registered midwives to order and administer covid-19 tests according to current protocols
received first shipment of 3,700 doses of moderna vaccine
first covid-19 vaccinations administered; first recipients were health care workers

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted sports, arts and culture activities to resume; spectators not permitted and practices limited to 50 people

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: opened adult service centres and regional rehabilitation centres for visits and volunteering
announced the addition of 230 long-term care beds in response to covid-19 outbreaks
permitted retail businesses to operate at 75% capacity

permitted organized gatherings (e.g., weddings, festivals, meetings, bingo, etc.) of 100 people indoors (or 50% capacity) and 150 outdoors, with distancing, until 11 p.m. (alcohol/food prohibited at 10 p.m.); organized clubs permitted to have cohorts of 15 people indoors and outdoors, with distancing
permitted indoor and outdoor fitness facilities to operate at 75% capacity (with distancing); spectators permitted during sport and cultural events (except schools)

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: amended the atlantic travel bubble rules, requiring people entering n.s. from n.l. to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival; arrivals from n.l. prior to 14 days before feb 10 should get tested

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: amended the atlantic travel bubble rules, requiring people entering n.s. from n.l. to complete the nova scotia safe check-in form prior to arrival (unless exempt—e.g., travelling workers, health and legal services, custody sharing)
announced the openings of pop-up centres and public health mobile health units for asymptomatic community testing

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: limited residents of long-term care homes to their designated caregivers in the halifax regional municipality and regions in hants and lunenburg counties; leave for medical appointments or drives remains permitted

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: required regular travellers (e.g., rotational/specialized workers, parents and children for child custody purposes) travelling outside n.s. or p.e.i. to have 3 mandatory covid-19 tests during their 14-day self isolation; modified definition of rotational workers, subjecting international workers to federal travelling requirements
entered phase 2 of the covid-19 immunization plan

expanded vaccine eligibility to include all hospital staff who may come into contact with patients and those who provide direct patient care (e.g., doctors and nurses in community settings, dentists, pharmacists); individuals will be vaccinated based on age
received 1st shipment of 13,000 doses of the astrazeneca vaccine
announced that nova scotians between the ages of 50 and 64 will be eligible to be vaccinated by the astrazeneca vaccine at 26 pharmacies and physician clinics across the province

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted travel to and from the restricted areas of halifax regional municipality, hants and lunenburg counties

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for halifax regional municipality, hants and lunenburg counties, permitted restaurants and licensed establishments to provide dine-in services 1 hour later, with the requirement to stop service by 10 p.m. and close by 11 p.m.

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for halifax regional municipality, hants and lunenburg counties, permitted arts and sports (recreational, amateur, professional) events in groups of 60 people without distancing for training, practices and regular competition; permitted spectators as long as host facilities have a gathering plan

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for halifax regional municipality, hants and lunenburg counties, permitted gatherings for weddings and funerals of up to 100 people indoors (or 50% capacity) and 150 people outdoors, with distancing; receptions and visitation remain prohibited

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: for halifax regional municipality, hants and lunenburg counties, opened public school gyms for after-school use
expanded vaccine eligibility to include individuals age 80 or older, born between jan. 1 and apr. 30
announced that individuals age 80 and older, born between sept. 1 and dec. 31, are now eligible for vaccination as outlined in the covid-19 immunization plan
formed an atlantic travel bubble with p.e.i. and n.b., allowing residents of atlantic canada to enter n.s. for non-essential travel
formed an atlantic travel bubble with p.e.i. and n.b., allowing residents of atlantic canada to enter n.s. without self-isolating for 14 days

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted household gatherings of households plus up to 10 others; permitted organized outdoor gatherings (e.g., weddings, social events, arts, wedding and funeral receptions, business meetings) of up to 150 and indoor gatherings of up to 100 people (or 50% capacity), with distancing; organized clubs can break into cohorts of 15 following day-camp guidelines

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted restaurants and licensed establishments to have dine-in services until 11 p.m. and close by midnight; permitted retail businesses and malls to operate at 75% capacity with public health measures

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted sports, arts and culture practising and performing of 60 people without distancing; permitted licensed and unlicensed establishments such as community centres, bowling, karaoke, charities and organized clubs to operate

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted visitors in long-term care facilities, adult residential centres and regional rehabilitation centres; permitted community access by residents in adult residential centres and regional rehabilitation centres
increased the time interval between the 1st and 2nd dose of covid-19 vaccines (pfizer, moderna and astrazeneca) to 16 weeks
announced that people age 75 to 79 are now eligible for vaccination

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: asked nova scotians to avoid non-essential travel to the city of edmundston and surrounding communities in n.b. as a result of increased cases

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: resumed atlantic travel bubble with n.l., allowing residents of n.l. to enter n.s. for non-essential travel; this reopening completed the full resumption of the atlantic travel bubble

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: resumed atlantic travel bubble with n.l., allowing residents of n.l. to enter n.s. without self-isolating for 14 days

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted malls and retail businesses to resume operating at full capacity, with distancing

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: permitted fitness facilities to resume operating at full capacity, with distancing; permitted sports practices, training and games, and arts and culture rehearsals and performances to have a maximum of 75 people including spectators, with distancing and masks recommended but not required

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: suspended the atlantic travel bubble with n.b., prohibiting non-essential travel (with some exceptions) and requiring completion of the nova scotia safe check-in form

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: suspended the atlantic travel bubble with n.b., requiring self-isolation for 14 days upon entry into n.s. (with some exceptions); travellers asked to be tested at the beginning and end of the self-isolation, and anyone exempt asked to get tested 3 times in their 1st 14 days in n.s.

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: suspended travel for people outside n.l. and p.e.i., prohibiting non-essential travel (with some exceptions) and requiring completion of the nova scotia safe check-in form

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: travellers from outside n.l. and p.e.i. asked to test at the beginning and end of the self-isolation, and anyone exempt asked to get tested 3 times in their 1st 14 days in n.s.
temporarily discontinued asymptomatic testing at assessment centres, except for recent travellers, close contacts of confirmed cases and those who have been at exposure locations

restricted non-essential travel into halifax regional municipality and its neighbouring communities of hubbards, milford, lantz, elmsdale, enfield, mount uniacke, south uniacke, ecum secum and trafalgar
mandated the wearing of masks for all students in schools

for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, limited indoor and outdoor gatherings to 5; weddings and funerals limited to 5 plus officiants; prohibited wedding receptions and funeral visitations or receptions

for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, prohibited in-person dining at restaurants and licensed establishments; limited retail businesses and malls to 25% capacity; closed all personal services such as hair salons, barbers and spas; prohibited faith gatherings

for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, prohibited sports practices, training, games, competitions or tournaments, arts and culture rehearsals and in-person performances, school gyms for community use; closed indoor fitness and recreational facilities; outdoor facilities permitted to continue operating with a maximum of 25 people; closed in-person services at libraries; closed casinos and gaming establishments
for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, mandated the wearing of masks in common areas of all indoor private businesses

for halifax regional municipality and its neighbouring communities, suspended indoor visitation in long-term care except for designated care providers; scheduled outdoor visits continue to be permitted; suspended all visitation and community access in homes licensed by the department of community services under the homes for special care act
for all of n.s. except for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, limited indoor and outdoor gatherings to 10

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities closed public schools (april 27) and moved to at-home learning (april 29)
for all of n.s., stopped school field trips and school-organized activities that bring students from different schools together

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s. except for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, suspended social events, wedding receptions and funeral visitation or receptions; indoor and outdoor gathering limit continues to be 10

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s. except for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, limited restaurants and licensed establishments to 50% capacity, stopping service at 11 p.m. and closing by midnight; personal services permitted to operate but cannot provide services that require removal of a mask; limited faith gatherings to 100 or 25% capacity indoors and 150 outdoors

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s. except for halifax regional municipality and neighbouring communities, limited casinos and gaming establishments to 50% capacity, stopping food and beverage service at 11 p.m. and closing by midnight; limited indoor sports and fitness facilities, museums and libraries to 50% capacity; outdoor fitness and recreation businesses limited to 25; limited business meetings and virtual gatherings and performances to 25; limited sports practices (games and competitions prohibited) and arts and culture rehearsals to 10 indoors and 25 outdoors

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., mandated the wearing of masks in common areas of all indoor private businesses

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., restricted non-essential travel between communities (defined as the municipality where someone lives)

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., closed all public and private schools

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., mandated the wearing of masks for staff, visitors and children over 2 years old in indoor child care settings

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., mandated the wearing of masks outdoors where distancing cannot be maintained

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., closed retail stores for in-person service except for essential goods and services; closed personal services such as hair salons, barber shops and spas; limited restaurants and licensed establishments to takeout or delivery; limited nova scotia liquor commission and essential goods and services stores to 25% capacity

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., closed all sports and fitness facilities, though outdoor recreation activities are allowed and encouraged to a maximum of 5 people with distancing; closed indoor recreation businesses, casinos and gaming establishments, museums and art galleries; limited libraries to pick-up and drop-off services

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: for all of n.s., suspended visitation and community access in long-term care homes (except for designated care providers) and homes licensed by the department of community services under the homes for special care act
announced that people age 40 to 54 are now eligible for the astrazeneca vaccine
announced that people age 50 to 54 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced that people age 45 to 49 are eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: closed the border to people moving to live in n.s.; closed the border to p.e.i. and n.l., with some exceptions for essential travel

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: suspended modified self-isolation for rotational workers; workers from outbreak zones must self-isolate for 14 days in a completely separate space from other people in their households, sharing only a frequently cleaned bathroom; workers may not attend non-emergent medical appointments except for mandatory covid-19 testing
announced that people age 40 to 44 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced a delay to the start of camping season at provincial camping parks until at least june; day use parks and campgrounds remain open
paused use of the astrazeneca vaccine for 1st doses
announced new travel application process for n.s. residents and essential travellers, including rotational workers; the application process uses the existing nova scotia safe check-in
announced that people age 35 to 39 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced that people age 30 to 34 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced that public and private schools will stay closed to in-person learning for the remainder of the school year
announced that people age 25 to 29 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: expanded the criteria for people moving to n.s. and announced additional flexibility for essential travel from p.e.i.
announced that people age 70 to 74 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced that people age 55 to 64 are now eligible for the astrazeneca vaccine
announced that people age 65 to 69 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced that people age 60 to 64 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced that people age 55 to 59 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced the delay of resuming of the atlantic travel bubble, which allows non-essential travel within the region, by 2 weeks

who: premier, department of health and wellness
what: province to enter a 14-day lockdown; "circuit breaker" restrictions will come into effect

who: nova scotia college of medical laboratory technologists
what: announced that medical laboratory technologists can practise virtually/remotely
announced $12.2 million to train more doctors, $914,000 to train more nurses
permitted day camps to have cohorts of 15 people indoors and outdoors, with distancing
announced pause of the use of astrazeneca’s covid-19 vaccine as the 1st dose
announced that people age 20 to 24 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)
announced that people age 12 to 19 are now eligible for vaccination (pfizer and moderna)

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: announced that in-person classes will resume at all n.s. public and private schools outside of halifax regional municipality and sydney

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: lifted the capacity limit on licensed child care centres and family daycare homes

who: department of education and early childhood development
what: announced that in-person classes will resume at all public and private schools in halifax regional municipality and sydney

who: service nova scotia and internal services, department of inclusive economic growth
what: eased liquor restrictions for restaurant takeout, including the expansion of the list of drinks permitted for takeout
released a new 5-phase reopening plan
announced that the province will enter phase 1 of the new reopening plan after reaching 50% threshold in 1st-dose vaccinations

as part of phase 1 of the new reopening plan,  permitted outdoor gatherings of 10 consistent contacts without distancing; weddings and funerals remain limited to 5 indoors but increased to 10 outdoors; receptions and visitations remain prohibited

as part of phase 1 of the new reopening plan, permitted restaurants and licensed establishments to open patios at maximum capacity with distancing between tables, a limit of 10 people per table and masks when people are not eating or drinking; and service stopping by 11 p.m. and closing by midnight; permitted all retail stores to operate at 25% capacity and personal services to resume by appointment; outdoor faith gatherings of 10 permitted; no capacity limit on drive-in services

as part of phase 1 of the new reopening plan, permitted fitness and recreation facilities to offer outdoor activities of 10 people with distancing, multiple groups of 10 that are distanced on their own property and one-on-one personal training indoors; permitted outdoor pools and organized sports practices to have groups of 10 people; permitted campgrounds to open for season and short-term camping with distancing between campsites; permitted professional arts and culture organizations to hold indoor rehearsals with 15 people; permitted drive-in theatres to operate with no capacity limits

announced lifting restrictions on within province travel except for cape breton regional municipality and into and out of areas of halifax regional municipality, hubbards, milford, lantz, elmsdale, enfield, mount uniacke, south uniacke, ecum secum and trafalgar; permitted domestic students to apply for entry if enrolled for the summer semester; expanded the criteria for end of life visits in n.s.

permitted outdoor visits for residents of long-term care; masks required for visitors but no distancing is required if the resident is fully vaccinated; permitted fully vaccinated residents of homes licensed by the homes for special care act to resume community access for work, therapy, recreation and family visits
resumed use of the astrazeneca vaccine for 2nd doses only
accelerated 2nd-dose appointments for nova scotians who received their 1st dose between mar. 11 and 21 and were originally scheduled to receive their 2nd dose between june 24 and july 3

accelerated 2nd-dose appointments to before june 30 for nova scotians who received their 1st dose of astrazeneca on or before apr. 21; astrazeneca or an mrna vaccine are options for the 2nd dose, but pfizer and moderna are recommended
accelerated 2nd-dose appointments for nova scotians who received their 1st dose on or before apr. 10 and were originally scheduled to receive their 2nd dose on or before july 24

announced the start of a voluntary testing program for travellers at halifax stanfield international airport: travellers will be provided with a self-swab pcr test; test results do not modify self-isolation requirements
